An excellent company. Typical work day is full of activity - even manic at times, but the organizations goals are made clear and your hard work will not go unnoticed. You hardly hear anyone say "that's not my job", or "there's always tomorrow". Intel invests a lot in building a culture that prevents roadblocks, going further than most companies to ensure their employees work together. The management structure is very dynamic. Rarely do you see a manager hold the same position for many years. Any management issues can usually be discussed 1:1 and resolved, but if need be brought to HR for resolution. The people I've worked with have been respectful and always willing to help. A challenging part of the job is adapting to constant change. What was top priority in the morning, is not necessarily the same one in the afternoon. The company execs listen to their employees, and the company benefits are hard to beat.Results-driven. Serious about their work but make time for some fun. Treat their employees with respect.

This internship was great for gaining experience from a analytical standpoint along with understanding how to properly conduct business in a professional setting. A typical day at Intel consisted of receiving in any shipments that had been ordered by the purchasing team, entering the assets into our database, and then delivering it to the specified team who ordered the equipment. Other job responsibilities included the managing and shipping of assets, coordinating with team leads with ongoing projects, managing a team of fellow interns on daily goals and project deadlines, and following up with upper management on daily, weekly, and monthly progress reportsGreat place to work and excellent business culture
You get what you put into it but you have to manage not getting consumed by work. The culture is good and creates a solid foundation of stability from organization to organization.Good company

I worked for them about 20 years. I was given excellent advancement opportunities, education, and very little micromanagement. Good monetary compensation, Excellent benefits, Incredible growth opportunities.

I'm not going to waste your time with my "typical day at work", suffice it to say these days were anywhere from 8 hours to 20+ hours long throughout my career. What did I learn? Well, I started as a contract tech writer and left two decades later as a Project Manager. Intel fully supported my education and growth goals, and in fact paid for most of my education. There is no such thing as stagnate work here - you are encouraged to grow and move on/up.

I had mostly great managers. in 20 years I had 2 I wouldn't work for again, and at least 4 I'd drop everything and return to work for. Intel has a culture that thrives on personal responsibility, especially for salaried employees. You are encouraged to think outside of the box, take informed risks, constructively confront even higher management. This is not a culture of firmly established hierarchy.You are hired for your skill set, encouraged to improve those skills, and all the while treated as an integral part of the corporation.

You are expected to work hard, take on responsibility, meet your commitments, be a team player, own your own future. This is not the environment for all applicants as it does take self-discipline, willingness to accept responsibility for failures, and the ability to shrug off some fairly strong personalities. They hire very skilled and well educated employees. You will be held to very highExcellent employer, good compensation, great coworkers

If there is a right way to do things and a wrong way to do things Intel now without a second though that everyone else in the world is doing things the wrong way. A place where old approaches such as SOC take on new life only when management discovers it's effecting their stock price. The majority of people working for Intel have never worked any place else and have no interest in ever working any place else and couldn't get a job on the outside anyways due to the lack of experiencing in doing anything any other way but the Intel way. This is the only company I have ever worked for that discourages employees interacting with the outside world going so far as to have their own internal conferences to make sure no one ask questions. Typical day:

Arrive at work. Check into ticketing system, local messaging system, and email. Remedy any issues that demand immediate attention (diagnosing and troubleshooting issues). Move on to any designated projects such as installation or removal of systems, setting up switches, managing local KVM solution, etc.

I've improved on my time management skills, how to structure and work on complex tasks, and my interpersonal and communication skills.

Management and coworkers are amiable, helpful, and concise.

The most difficult part of the job is navigating through the complex ticketing system and it's foibles.

The most enjoyable part of the job is the office culture.Systems administration

A typical day at Intel involves meeting with customers and teams across the world. Some meetings can be early in the morning or late in the day/evening depending on who the attendees are and where they are physically located at. Management is great and encourages thinking outside of the box and risk taking. Teams and co-workers are great in that everyone is supportive and helpful and respectful. The hardest part of the job is saying good-bye to a fellow co-worker when they leave a team or the company as we have all evolved into an extended family.

The most enjoyable part of the job is the interaction and learning about new cultures whether it is virtually or via International travel. For a company that employs +/- 100K workers around the world, it is wonderful to know that Intel is a place where "everyone knows your name". Other perks Intel provides are a full cafeteria with free beverages and fruits, which includes a breakfast menu until 10:00am and then Lunch from 11:00am to 2:00pm. They also provide an on-site medical clinic for both employees and their families, a gym, a putting green, a basketball court, a bank, and many other concierge services.

The most valuable lesson I have learned as an employee of Intel is that no matter your background, your education, your religion, your gender, or ethnicity everyone has something of value to contribute to success of the Intel Vision and Strategic Imperatives.My Career at Intel

Influence decisions aiming at saving millions of dollars through cost reduction.
Presentations to Senior Vice Presidents, Directors to apprise them on the Industry trends in the Mobile Industry.
There is an environment of how to stay ahead of the competitive and what can you do to achieve that goal.

Intel is a great company to work for but moving up the ranks from a contractor (green badge) to a full Intel employee is tough (blue badge). Often, contract employees are used for 18 months and no benefits or likelihood of advancement.

I worked here for 34 yrs, grew up only knowing Intel and their work culture. I loved every minute of it, but it was time for a change. I was a Failure Analysis Engineer at Intel and did mostly technical work. (quality control in a lab environment) I created and improved continuously our failure analysis process, by creating and improving wet and dry etchbacks, using chemicals and gases. Then using it on computer chips and or full wafers that manufacturing made, but not up to par, so I located the problems and try to improve yield. I also maintained all the supplies and equipment's. I handled all our administration tasks by ordering supplies, organizing lab and writing and training all new hires on safety and procedures.Fun place but yet task oriented

Intel maintains that employees are important, however their actions are to the contrary. Certain benefits are available, but only to employees with several years at the company. Office politics is the primary function of Intel Corp., whereas semi-conductor manufacturing is the secondary. If you plan to excel on your own merit, this is not the company in which to do so. If you plan on getting ahead through Deliberate Machiavellianism and yelling at others to focus attention away from your ineptitude, this is your company. Intel is the most hostile work environment that I've ever been in, which includes fighting in the war. They've offered me a position four times since I left their employment and I've turned it down every time.Hostile work environment

Good and fast paced, almost each day. I learned lots of technical things-- good formal technical training.

A typical day at Intel almost always includes a meeting. Intel believes that if you know where you stand in the "big picture" that you will have more job satisfaction and therefore be more productive. I believe that there are managers that do not follow Intel culture which makes for an uninviting work environment. Otherwise managers are easy to work with and communicate with. For the most part my co-workers were of the highest caliber. That's one of the reasons Intel is number 1 chip manufacturer. The hardest part of a mask designer's job is to find opportunities for advancement. If you do not have a job-specific degree, you will not be eligible for advancement. When I had hired on 14 years ago, this was not the case and this proved to be the case for a while. Then Intel reverted back to being "degree centric" again. The most enjoyable part of being a mask designer at Intel is that you can transfer to multiple departments at one site or transfer to multiple sites around the world. You will work on cutting edge technology. Every two years you learn a new process, new designs and new tools. This proved to be very challenging and exciting.Great place to work depending on which department you work for.
Loved working for Intel. Great company. Intel work life is great. Great stress free environment.Great place to work
Really challenging environment but great place to develop your skills. Would recommend it as a great place to work.Great Company

Managing a program at Intel is very challenging and very rewarding. My day always started before 6 am because I worked with teams around the world. Interacting with these teams was the most enjoyable part of my job. Working across cultures brings along it's difficulties and being able to overcome these provide job satisfaction. The hardest part of my job was having the accountability of the program but having no real authority over the people doing the work. Because of other program priorities, as a Program Manager I had to be creative to make sure the work was finished as planned.Intel Program Management

What I like about working here is the variety of works, as a technician, i get to work on both hardware and software troubleshooting.

What I dislike about this company is the culture. Contingent worker is basically treated like outsiders, there is no promotion, no recognition for hard work, innovation. Intel treated employees like an EXCEL spreadsheet file. No human side of the employee is important. Intel tried to create a value "great place to work" to hide the weakness of the culture in dealing with employees.

A typical day at work was spent operating large machines to coat or develop 12" wafers.

I learned a lot about the process that the wafers go through to make one computer chip or processor.

Co-workers were wonderful! We worked compressed shifts (12 hours) and we were a great team, always willing to help each other out.

The hardest part of the job was working the 48 hour weeks in 4 days.

The most enjoyable part of the job was our 'team-building' games, lunches and dinners.Goal oriented company

A typical day at work is calendar management, handling emails, some fires that need to put out. What I learned from Intel over the past 11.5 years was how to get along with all different types of people and cultures. Intel is a very divers company and I believe that skill will carry me through life. Management was good, through most of my tenure, however, I did have my bumps in the road. I think the hardest part of my job, was anticipating what was going to happen next. Intel has lots of org changes and last minute interruptions. It taught me how to be one step a head. The most enjoyable part of my job, was know I made a difference in the group or someones career. Being an admin, you have to be the " mother" figure. You have to go above and beyond for the people you work with, to help make them successful, which helps the company be successful.Busy place to work but very rewarding

As a seasoned equipment technician in multiple manufacturing environments throughout Intel's fab fleet, a typical day would consist of sustaining manufacturing equipment, driving Intel's one of kind culture, and developing my skills and training to further advance my career within Intel's vast corporate environment. The broad management staff always had a pulse on the ever changing tech industry cycle, ready and able to adjust to it. They also welcomed the advancement of my career whether it was participating in cross functioning teams or pursuing my advanced degree. My co-workers were wonderful because we were like a family in which I still keep in touch with. Personally, the hardest part of the job was working night shift for a short period of time, being unable to spend time with my kids on certain nights. The most enjoyable part(s) of the job was the schedule(compressed work weeks), working only 14 days a month; the ability to sculpt your own path for career growth.Excellent corporate environment to grow and learn

They have been very successful in microprocessors and have a monopoly on them, but other areas are suspect. They tried to get into more areas by acquiring companies. This did not work. Most of these ventures have failed. Their main product is Powerpoint presentations rather than chips. I have never worked anywhere that was as bureaucratic as Intel. Most of the employees are conceited and buy into the whole "Intel culture" but they are fooling themselves. They support a program of internal transfers, but I found that there are a lot of people there that use this to be moving targets so they do not have to actually produce anything. I was there 3 years and was effected by 4 reorganizations.Not a nice place to work

Learned from the new hires and the old hands. Each one had different styles so I had to be able to change the way we do things or be miserable all the time. I worked with some of the best people in the world there. This gave me insight to different cultures and ways of looking at things. The hardest part of the job was to find and accept the root cause of a problem. This could be very surprizing. Periodically interface with IT Managers, Network Administrators, Hardware Engineers to discuss and implement processes based on the needs of the client.

JLL has a lot of great resources like 24/7 tech support that you just don't get a most companies (like when I needed help setting up a VPN to work on Christmas morning from home...). JLL Contract job.

I went through 4 Facility Managers within 9 months.

*Let that be an indicator to the work culture, environment, and management.

Non-existent JLL training to do your job properly.

Non-existent help from upper management. Ghosting you when you email your manager. I repeatedly asked for help and was talked down to by a manager who was an off- site manager who was supposed to be giving assistance to us, as we we're still trying to learn our jobs. Very hostile person. This person should be fired. It's a true sign as to why they can't keep employees in this particular site.

Asking you to do more jobs without compensation, or proper training. Essentially throwing work on you that you don't know how to do.

Absolutely no support or direction. I guess that's why they've gone through so many managers for the last 15 years.

Managers messing with your pay!

GM managers were demanding and demeaning towards JLL employees, as well as their own employees. GM employees making inappropriate comments, making everyone feel real uncomfortable.

Toxic and hostile work environment! Almost criminal!

The company is financially stable and treats employees with respect. I have met a lot of coworkers that have been with the company for over ten years.

I have worked for global corporations as well as small to medium organizations, and JLL is by far the best company that I have ever worked for.Best company I have ever worked for!

JLL doesn't have a competitive salary package but they get you with their benefits. You start out with 18 PTOs which increases to 23 upon your three year anniversary but it's not worth the salary. Fun to work with the people there but no one is looking out for you. I have worked for JLL on 2 different accounts and they are night and day. The JLL Benefits and perks are second to none. PTO is great, holidays and healthcare are great. My most recent account is more about penny pinching and dealing with frustrated and sometimes irate clients because you cant get work done due to budgetary slowdowns and cost deferments. I also have to deal with onerous paperwork for the sake of paperwork and redundant systems that only make getting work done confusing.Great comapany to work for some accounts are better than others

Fantastic overall company culture, leader in commercial real estate. Great place to learn the ropes and be given a chance...especially for new graduates. Financially successful, stable company. There are too many incompetent managers and supervisors that are promoted and kept on in spite of their inadequacies. However that can be expected with a large company. I came to JLL as an intern during the summer of 2014 and it was one of my best work experiences of my life. Working for JLL has been a pleasure. I have had three different managers in the year and a half that I have been with the company and I am pleased to say that they were all extremely helpful and constructive. My work hours are flexible, being that all my clients are in the west coast. I start work at 11 am and end at 8pm. I can also work from home as much or little as I would like. As far as compensation, I believe that through the work I have demonstrated I deserve to make more. All management agrees with me but the team does not have a ton of money being that we are fairly small and new within JLL. I have a masters degree in Industrial Engineering and management concentration and do environmental efficiency work for my current position. I have learned and developed many skills and can genuinely say that JLL has taught me more than my four years at school when it comes to management, running a team, being a leader, and developing your skills. The work culture is friendly and inviting. My coworkers are extremely helpful and the atmosphere is very team oriented. Although I love working for this company and greatly enjoy my job I do not see a set path for my career advancement. I would like to have more responsibilities and challenges and would like to move up in my career.work review

In my time working for Kaiser I learned a great deal on using there scanning equipment and process.

I really enjoyed my Supervisor at the time who really helped everyone out regarding proper protocol and procedures. She was also key to always insuring the work got done in a timely manner.

The workplace culture was very friendly everyone knew what they needed to do and did it well. We had a good team with everyone helping one another should the need arise.

Kaiser works with loyalty to their employees, which is why it is hard to get a job in the first place with them. They first post the position within the department allowing for anyone to advance within. If no one wants it then they allow anyone from other departments to apply, and then still if no one wants it they allow people from the outside to apply. Even then, it's competitive! Depending on your position and shift will determine what your hours are. For my position, there was a clear training period and a list of what you were supposed to learn. The workplace culture was very supportive and there was always clear communication between everyone - from lower staff to management to other department heads. The hardest part of the job is keeping calm during an emergency code, but that will take practice. I learned about being much more observant, clear communication, and the importance of getting information to people as fast as possible. The best part about working here I think is the culture, because everyone - and I mean everyone - is really supportive. Yes there are bad days and good days like any company but at least here, the average day was a good one working with good people.Hard to get in, but worth it

A typical work day for a clinical nurse consists of answering phone to address member concerns, assisting the Physicians with members appointment and in charge of day to day tasks to aide in success of the clinic. The culture can differ drastically from clinic to clinic.Productive environement

Management can either be encouraging or difficult to deal with, depending on the person who's in charge. This was the worst place I have ever worked!

Kaiser is a very professional environment, so only the best and top work is expected but there are so many incentives. Kaiser pays high wages for each level and division of staff they have. I can only speak about my experience at the specific location I was working. The job itself was not stressful, it was the environment and some of the co workers.I also found it to be" clique-ish". It is terrible when a person is new and still learning the "Kaiser Way" that there is constantly negative criticism. Instead of correcting the issue, the management would rather let you burn and sink. Kaiser does pay well and the benefits are awesome, but it is not worth putting your license and integrity at risk. Like I said, it is not all of Kaiser I'm speaking of, just one specific unit and location. I did meet some awesome people there, but I met more people that are not. Everyone's experience is different, but for me it was not very pleasant. Don't just look at the pay, look at the culture when deciding on working here. Good Luck!!Think twice about working here

I loved working at Kaiser it was my favorite place to work. I am hoping now to get into a phlebotomist position, and work with great people and great managers.I learned a lot about patient care and resposibilities

Articulated in the resume. Kaiser is a great company with many opportunities. There are regional and program office resources to aide all positions. Great infrastructure and excellent healthcare.Great company with abundant opportunities

The company as a whole is amazing, although there are a few departments to stay far away from. I will not name them, but they are toxic and dead ends for your career. Do your homework before accepting a position. Ask friends or friends of friends who work there, about which departments to stay clear of. The company has a great mission and seems to be dedicated to the health of their workforce, although they turn a blind eye on specific, rogue departments that are a nightmare to work for, but are critical to the business. HR is not helpful and is untrustworthy, so if you find yourself in this kind of department, you are either stuck, must live with it, or figure out how to get out. Again, this is not all of KP, but just be aware of the culture of the department, before accepting a position.Toxic work environment, discouraged to have work/life balance

Management is so so. You have to be on their good side.

loved my bosses. loved my big cubicle. loved working with nurses and staff on the phone. love the flexibility i was given.call center

Kaiser Permanente can be a great place to work. Working within a team is like family. Kaiser Permanente (Northern California) is a complex organization with a great mission and most employees are very committed to serving the organization and it's members. Very top-down hierarchy and while change can happen, it doesn't happen quickly. Moving up in the organization is based on relationships. Very hectic pace due to the nature of serving so many members and trying to achieve high healthcare rankings. Workplace culture varies widely between business entities (hospital/health plan/medical group) and across medical centers and departments. A typical day is fast-paced, lots of objectives to meet, and great people to collaborate with. Innovation is slow in comparison to other industries (e.g., tech, biotech), but possible with determination.An organization with a great mission.

When I was at Kaiser Permanente it was one of the best jobs I have ever worked. From the people to the patients to wages and vacation.

KP is a good place to work in terms of compensation and benefits considering it's a nonprofit. Kaiser has a great KPLearn site where I have been able to increase my technological knowledge and advanced my Microsoft application skills. The culture is inviting, with many others eager to learn and advance in their careers. The hardest part of my job, , is I came to Kaiser feeling like a big fish in a small pond. I grew with my last company as far as I could as they were much smaller than KP. I took a position to get me started with KP but with the hundreds of applications coming in, I find it difficult to advance and compete. I feels like my past experience is overlooked by my current position. The most enjoyable part of my job is that I do not ever get stressed, I am well supported by my manager and peers.Kp

Kaiser is a great company to work for fun some stress full days ,management is good they have every culture in there facility .They teach me how to deal with difficult intubation set up emergency lines this is a fast pace environment take it or leave it, the hardest part when anesthesia don't work first thing in the morning the enjoyable the people the music that give us that drive I look forward going back to work for them great place to work.Very fun safe place to work.

If you're new to Kaiser, its a great place to work for. There's good work life balance. I am surrounded by really good ppl who are dedicated to serve the company's mission. It is inspiring. I am proud to work for them. However, there isnt much growth opportunity because the culture and management doesn't promote within or help you advance to the next level. Its a culture that sits between public companies and government agencies.Great stable company but with limited growth

working with kaiser was a great experience. was able to travel and meet many new people and the company provided me and my team lots of amazing benefits. it was literally that best job Ive ever had to dateoverall great experiance

The culture is great. Hard working but laid back.

New management team is very open to new ideas and is constantly seeking ways to improve employee experience.

Job is the same ever day but this is made interesting by delivering to different customers everydayVery compatative

Working at an advice triage RN for Kaiser is akin to working in a prison camp. En masse, you are assigned specific breaks and cannot use the bathroom or get a drink or snack outside of those times. There are cameras EVERYWHERE so there is literally nowhere to make a personal call; you are even forbidden from leaving the building during your lunch break. Dress code is extremely bizarre and random, no scarves or jewelry--which is odd b/c there is no patient contact. There is extreme tension between management and staff. Daily, edicts are handed down with new rules which are enforced in a draconian manner. Every call you receive is recorded and you are encouraged as a new advice triage nurse to ask your charge for assistance or advice. When you do, and execute that exact instruction, you can be written up if it veers at all from the "manual." Further, do not think that asking the advice MD on call for his/her advice will be heeded. Even their call on difficult decisions (whether a pt should go to ER or primary dr) is irrelevant if it doesn't follow the 'manual." And no amount of documentation will cover you. BEWARE. I have never experienced such a back-stabbing culture in my many years in healthcare. The pay and benefits are excellent but you must muscle through the tricks and games played by your management.Pay and benes are excellent, work culture treacherous

Enjoyed the amazing way the employees are warm and inviting. The benefits were amazing and everyone was friendly. The customers made the day go by with different stories.The Most Enjoyable Part of the Job
Best company to work for and be a part of hands down . Everything from the location to the culture of the employees . I couldn't be happierExcellence is Excellence

I was a temp and everyone treats you as an actual employee. I learned a lot. Management is very professional. Helping patients is very rewarding. The culture is all about customer service.A great place to work out and great co workers

Where do I begin... worked at the Hayward, CA Kaiser Permanente as a mental health clinician... The place was like working in the institution in the movie/book One flew over the Cuckoo's nest. The master's level clinicians provided most of the direct services yet the psychiatrists received most of the pay and perks, including not having to participate in weekend on-call duties and being able to earn shares of Kaiser stock. Very strong caste system. The director of this department was kind of like an absentee landlord, so employees were fighting amongst themselves to hire family members, friends and to receive other types of informal perks. A lot of bullying and negative politics. Though it's such a big organization I would guess that if you have a competent supervisor they can shield their department from some of the negatives. But overall, a crazy place to work.Dysfunctional work environment, may have been that particular facility.

Tipical day very busy, I learn all the procedures in hospital, how to treat all workers and respect them, divorce culture, hardest part is time, the different challenges if every daybusy and very productive
Great place to work. Great workplace culture. Great best practices workplace environment. Up to date technology used in patient care.Great place to work
Kaiser is a great place to work, I love how they work with there employees to make the work environment fun and pleasant. And how everyone works as a team.Great place to work

Each day at Kaiser we focused on finding new ways to continue being the top health care provider. This allowed for an environment to be able to express yourself. As well as, room for improving the company. I learned about the importance of team work, and being able to work well with other. There way a big difference in the departments that recognized this. The management were excellent. They have always been their for me with person matters, education leave, or whatever was going on. As well as personable. Kaiser is very multicultural. I love to learn, so working with many different cultures opened my eyes to many things that I was not aware of. The hardest part of the job was reminding myself I am human. I hate making mistakes. I take it very personal by being hard on myself. I love food. Everyone at the job loved food just as much as I do. So everyday we found new places to eat.Great work environment

Typical day at work is always Fun, Laughter, close relationship with the Manager, supervisors and overall great environment.

The national organization is outstanding. They truly care about their members and employees. The local employees are some of the best I've ever worked with. The most talented senior leaders are leaving quickly if they haven't already. In the last several years with the change to a new regional president, the Hawaii region has been difficult to work for and is becoming more detached from the community. Senior leaders (with rare exception) treat people poorly and then try to force a "be happy or be punished" agenda. Their young leaders can't grow and leave unless they are from the mainland and they at least stay with Kaiser. Sad to see a once thriving, happy place to work turn into a place of mediocrity and a culture of fear and ignorance.Great national org, poor Hawaii leadership
it is excellent place to work. And its employee oriented and enjoyed to work with Kaiser Permanente. Its hard to find cons here but great place to work with.good

GREAT place to work the environment was very wonderful and the people were all very helpful to everyone. I loved working here. Management were all very caring and had a personal connection with you.Great Place

There is nothing about hardest part of the job, everyday is sensible to work.Good Place to Learn about the new tools

The job is very easy, the culture of the staff is friendly, supervisor are always communicating with you and look for advise from you to improve workflow and day to day operations. We have great trainers and various opportunity available for career growth.Great Place to Work

Kaiser pays top dollar to nurses, as we are given raises twice a year for the first five years, then, annually by union, and every other year by by Kaiser. The raises are about 4% which is almost $2.00/hr each raise. I started as a new grad 8 years ago at 32.00/hour and am now at 58.00/hour, not adding night, or weekend differential. Our benefits are excellent. Our union dues are not high, as many people think, but they really do not do much for us.
The management, however, is not that great. They encourage a culture of computer nursing, by not caring about staffing needs, or workload ratios. And even when we win service awards, we are not given recognition. I know nurses complain about this often, but we have too many traveler nurses who can not wait to leave at the end of their contract, stating that they NEVER had to work under such stressful conditions.
The best part about Kaiser is the people we work with. It feels like we all have to pull together as a family does to get through the stressful conditions.great pay for stressful environment
Normal working day , everyday you learned diff things about your work, management takes care of the employee, co workers are helpful and easy to get along.fun place to work
This is an AMAZING hospital!! They are in the cutting edge of technology and have a great staff. I would reccomend them to all my friends and family.Amazing Hospital
Bad management and no growth. The equipment is from the 1980's and the coworkers are all afraid of the next lay off. There were no team building events, and no time off.Bad place to work

Kaiser has given me the opportunity to connect with my community by encountering interesting new cultures and customs by being involved and helping in any way possible. I have achieved many goals by expanding my horizons while I demonstrate commitment and moral support as a professional healthcare provider.One word "Fabulous"
Everything about the job was great: The benefits, the people, the administration and the doctors and healthcare staff. Would recommend to anyone.Great place to work!

never had a bad day, awesome management, great co-workers, wonderful customers , truly blessed to work for them, the hardest part of the job was loosing it due to shutting down in ohioloved working for Kaiser

Kaiser Permanente is a strong advocate for healthy living for the members as well as its employees. Kaiser holds exercises, yoga sessions open for members and workers. The hardest part of the job is trying to satisfy every single patient. The most enjoyable part of the job is creating a safe and comfortable environment for all of my patients.Patient Centered Care

Always encouraging staff to thrive at work.Great place to work

Supporting managers priority change, you adjust, communicate and manage time to get the job(s) done. Co-worker(s) will pitch in.It was great to be a part of Kaiser Permanente Medical Team. They provided company on line classes to for growth opportunities .

A typical day involved a ton of paperwork that changed from day tot day. Learning was mandatory, as Kaiser did use the internet to set up job specific training support.

You were expected to manage subcontracts, estimates, schedules, daily construction RFI's, submittals, and daily logs. Ensure the crew is on track and doing what was expected; and manage as much as 15 projects at one time of all different sizes.

Coworkers were mostly stressed out from the work load and often sick and tired. The hardest part of the job was all the unnecessary politics that generated from managers and administrators that made construction harder and harder to do each day making the old saying of "too many chiefs and not enough Indians" a reality at Kaiser Permanente.

The most enjoyable part was seeing how the doctors, nurses and support staffs enjoyed the remodeled facilities generated from the construction. It made the hospital look clean and ready to tend to customers needs in regards to health care.Health Care TI work for the most part.

Working at Kaiser Permanente was a pleasure and wonderful opportunity. Coworkers inspired me to aim for higher goals and were wiling to help me achieve such goals. The atmosphere was professional. I enjoyed that each member of Kaiser works really hard towards providing the best quality health care for each patient.Inspiring Workplace

A typical day was very very demanding because of the high volume and complexity of the work. The thing that I learned was the ability to maintain a high level of concentration. Management was also OK they had some good managers. My coworkers were also highly skilled. The hardest part about the job was just showing up. The most enjoyable part was knowing that I provided the best patient care possible.good

Doing different job every day, opportunity to learn on wide scale, Great Management team, Fun and enjoying my time with my co-workers, hardest part of this job was low pay, most enjoyable resolving issue and getting compliments from management which motivate me to work harder.My favorite Place to work

I learned all the tips and tricks of the trade that they had to offer while i worked under my seniors.Proffesional, kind, helpful

Many tenured team members. Knowledgeable and caring. Never any hesitation on the part of many team members to pitch in and help out to get the job done.It's not the work, it's the people who make work wonderful.

I really enjoyed my department. They worked well with each other as team players. Supervisor and Manager welcomed suggestions to make work more efficient and faster. Working for Kaiser Permanente one feels as though they are part of one large team. This is often a cliche but in this case it is true. They expect you to meet or exceed your metrics but give you the tools to meet them. There is a lot of politics involved but that is to be expected here in the SF Bay Area. Most of my days involved closing a lot of new business. Some days I attended community health fairs and worked on administrative tasks.A great company that provides incomparable training. Trying to motivate a stagnant culture. To influence them to want to do more. The employees are union protected, thus making it impossible to discipline via corrective action and require nurses to seek to improve their skillsFabulous company, challenging employees

Kaiser is a fantastic environment to advance skills in technology and management. The culture in IT jobs can be fun but requires a high degree of building relationships. Large IT organizations, like Kaiser's have many challenges in aligning the business objectives with advancing technology. This requires constant evolution on the organization to align or readjust to the needs of the business. Kaiser is no different than most and does a good job in rewarding those who can drive forward while partnering with others. The most success is found in those who manage or embrace a more egoless approach and strive to influence for the greater benefit to Kaiser.Challenging and Noble Cause

A typical day at work for me was shadowing different department heads and sitting in on meetings, getting a background look into how Kaiser is ran and what goes into making a massive HMO run smoothly and efficiently. I also spent a lot of time with assistants and learning different clerical duties and helping them with small projects.

I learned that it takes a village to make a healthcare organization run smoothly, with different departments being able to communicate with each other and utilize all of their skills and abilities in a way that everyone benefitted from.

The most enjoyable part of the job was getting to know the different staff there and see how much they really cared about the patients. Working at kaiser has opened my eyes to the healthcare corporate industry regarding high level healthcare Kaiser is no different when it comes to big profit. CEO and MD makes lots if income while our union has been in talks with Kaiser for the past 4 years. It's amazing to me how separated and disingenuous things can be it's a climate that's difficult to work in with the politics. Our clinic is under staffed not the best working conditions most of the therapist have to share offices. Our manager over the past not sure how many years has tried to get adequate office space for groups and for therapist. We are booked solid with too many clients who need intensive services case management and so many more services. Sometimes as a therapist I feel demoralized and disrespected and under appreciated. Times are changing and from my perspective not for the best. If you're a therapist think outside the box as a MFT or a LCSW please think outside the box and take the time to think about what your career goals are and the value of being a therapist . If you like being in a pressure cooker job or a job that pulls everything out of you then go work for Kaiser. But I'm telling you think about your emotional well-being and what you may've to give up to work in a pressure cooker.Over worked

I've really enjoyed working in the Kaiser culture and environment. I would room them, take vitals, ask how their morning or day has been going, chart information in patients chart. I would then give the paper work to the provider.
From working there I have learned many ways to handle difficult situations. How to run a providers schedule. My coworkers work great, we got along well and worked well together. They all taught me a lot. The hardest part of the job was not being enough for them. The most enjoyable part was being happy to go to work every dayGreatful
Awesome benefits, great hours, and coworkers are like family!Loved this Job
nice place to work for. the doctors and the staff are friendly. pt are nice. Great Benefits!!!!!nice place to work for
Great company.Good culture and extremely bright people. I grew the most over my career at this firm. If not for the travel schedule I would want to continue to work for this firm.Great Company

Great people with caring, intelligent and thought leadership for the most part. Good opportunity to grow as a professional. Good overall culture. Management was better than EY in my experience.Great overall firm

. Not in the league of other Big 4 in terms of opportunity and growth but it's an Okay Company to work with.
. Projects are assigned based on politics but not necessarily on skillset and demand/fit.No comments

Management and teammates are extremely helpful in guiding career goals and team goals. Wonderful atmosphere that strives for success as well as work/life balanceWonderful place with great people

Typical day is different, stressful culture and cutthroat . Learned alot on the job, but not career I want to pursue in the future. Great learning opportunity however.Stressful and Long hours

Working for KPMG was a great place to start my career. Being surrounded by intelligent, motivated people pushed me to learn and gain a plethora of different experiences.Fast Paced High Stress Environment

If you were not part of the so-called "gang", which I was not, then you were never allowed to work with/or on certain clients...Providence office was ill managed

Enjoyed my time at KPMG. Worked in a fast paced environment with professionals and managed new hire program. The culture was team based and respect for diversity. The best HR job.Fast paced professional enviroment

Great work life balance and growth opportunity. KPMG has a strong culture of people first and innovation within the corporate structure. I highly recommend KPMG for any professional that want to grow.Work Balance

Management with its open-door policy was the best and something that I have undertaken as something to make sure I use with my staff at all times and under any circumstance.It was a great place to work.

The team I worked with had a good collaboration with each other. Although there were times the days were long, the people there helped make the time go by. I had excellent coaching and teamwork was essential to get the job done on time.Relaxed environment, pleasant people

I would recommend the company to anyone looking for audit or tax experience, however, the culture of the company is less than uplifting. It is a public accounting firm. everyone keeps their head down.not the best culture
Loved working at KPMG. The #1 firm out of the Big 4. I recommend working there. You will learn a lot, build great relationships, and have great career advancement.Amazing Firm

company gives excellent benefits
workplace is very professional but comfortable
management is fair but very competitive
room for improvement and promotionvery competitive

The pros are good pay, benefits, and lots of paid time off. The work day is flexible as long as you put in 8 hours. The job work/life balance is very good. Great place to work, with great people. This was one of the best places I have ever had the pleasure of working. I learned that even when things are great, there is no such thing as job security.Diverse and fun place to work with free ice cream summers

Some of the KPMG managers will put things on evaluation without ever speaking to you about it before hand. They also gossip about other team members constantly.

Working at KPMG definitely you can learn a lot, KPMG has great training program.

benefits, perks and PTO above average

worked in HR departments very nice people. great place to work great atmosphere nice campus very laid back atmosphere work life balance is great. they value employees.Great

Great CIO that tries to turn the IT around from very outdated work style and culture. Old style management.

i had a great work experience.working environment was very friendly and team oriented. all employes were recognized for their hard work to boost the energy..hardworking and very productive enviorment

Of all the Big 4 firms I've worked for or had as my auditor, KPMG stands out as the most pleasant of them all. The culture is one that includes, not ostracizes it's staff, seniors and managers. very political and conservative, all depends on who you work for - beware of insecure people...worst out of four Big 4; however, there are some good pockets in the organization but overall like working for government without benefitsdepend on your manager

KPMG was my first job out of college. It was a great job to start my professional career and I enjoyed being a part of an audit team and learning about the ins and outs of different businesses. I also started with a large group of college graduates which made for fun office events and parties. The environment was a little too cut-throat for me and I did not see myself working there long-term.Great first professional job/tough environment

Definetly KPMG is probably the best big 4 accounting firm to work for. The work environment is very friendly and the salaries and benefits are incredible. I had a wonderful job/position. I worked for and with a very fun, and professional team and company.

I enjoyed meeting new people everyday and keeping in touch with all alumni over my 22 years. I enjoyed watching co-workers start as staff accountants and become Managing Directors, get married, have children, etc.

Work life balance is a total lie at this company. They rarely treat their people with humanity, you will have to travel extensively on top of 50-60 hour work weeks. They will tell you travel is Monday-Thursday, I only had one engagement where that was the case. All other were Monday thru Friday.

Pay is usually higher than you will find in similar jobs with other non-consulting companies, but their benefits aren't really that great. Insurance is expensive, poor 401(K) matching, they give max of 2.5% if you contribute at least 5%.

Job security is always contingent on not crossing of the wrong person.

Management will frequently dump secretarial tasks on lower level individuals who are rarely thanked for their efforts.

Job culture is a bunch of Type A hyper competitive, who can brown-nose kind of environment.Drone workforce used as cash cows

A Great Workplace: KPMG is recognized by a variety of external organizations for being a great place to work and build a career for all its people. For example, FORTUNE 100 Best Companies to Work For, LearningElite Top Ten, Universum's World's Most Attractive Employers, Universum Top 100 Ideal Employers for Young Professionals; DiversityInc Top 50 Companies for Diversity, Training Magazine's Top 10 Hall of Fame, Working Mother 100 Best Companies for Working Mothers, Working Mother Best Companies for Multicultural Women, Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index, Top 100 Military Friendly Employers, 100 Best Adoption-Friendly Workplaces, and Best Employer for Asian Pacific American Professionals.

A Great Portrait of History: The firm has a rich history of doing great work and making a difference, not only for its clients and its people, but for society at large.

A Collaborative Culture: Just like an orchestra, the firm comes together and perform as one team to reach its full potential and achieve great things.

A High-Performance Culture: Committed to having the best people with the skills and determination to deliver above and beyond; and about aspiring to the next level.

Flexible WorkLife Balance: Committed to offering its people access to a range of flexible schedules and arrangements that work for them while also meeting the needs of the firm.

Sound Core Values: Leads by example; work together; respect the individual; seek the facts and provide insight; open and honest in communication; committed to its communities and acts with integrity.

EncoreHigh-performance and collaborative culture with strong core values and great work-life balance

Employer provided quality training on a daily basis. There was great opportunity for advancement within the company. There were great mentors within the company to help you achieve your professional goals.Employer provided quality training.
Very poliitcal, Business development is required at all levels. Culture of promoting the very young rather than those who are experienced.No work life balance

KPMG will provide you with a solid name for your resume, great exposure, and even better experience. However, this is offset by the overwhelming number of hours you need to work and the stress caused by short deadlines. Most places outside of the Big 4 firms will compensate you for this, but not KPMG and not other Big 4. You will be paid well below your peers outside of public accounting. The only thing that makes the day managable is that KPMG maintain a strong culture amongst staff and managers. Essentially, you will enjoy who you work with 15 hours a day.Good name and good experience at a cost

The people are great!

It was really the first professional company I worked for after leaving retiring from the service. I was relatively new to the civilian work force. They welcomed me with open arms. My office manager made sure I was comfortable in my new position. The door was always open for any questions I may have had. The environment was always joyful, my co-workers were great to be around. And the company itself had so much to offer.

I really enjoyed my duties. Even when we moved from the 32nd floor to the 27th. Wow....that was a week I will never forget. Files, records, office dÃ©cor.

I learned a lot about corporate America and office politics. It really made me a more experienced person.A really great place to grow and succed....

I've worked at this company for almost 20 years. A typical work day can be challenging since I do not know what to expect when I walk in the door. I've learned how to multitask very well at this company.

KPMG is one of the world's largest accounting firms. It offers competitive salaries and benefits, and attracts a wide range of professionals.

The atmosphere is one that doesn't encourage work/life balance, and is rather stressful, to the point that many people burn out after a brief period.Big Four accounting firm with a high-stress atmosphere

KPMG leads in the offered services, but the culture and environment is very much behind the curve.

In HR, you may seem very disconnected from the rest of the firm and leadership lacks the training to help bridge the gap and connect the right people.

The matrix is set up to have three or more teams doing one job. Nobody is able to identify nor put in place to direct the traffic between internal processes.

The technology is also very dated and makes it hard and the silos between practices makes it hard to serve the clients and internal stakeholders.Legacy Company Not Very Open For Change

KPMG has a lot of great perks. As an associate, I came in with 25 days of vacation, a great salary, and the ability to work from home if I needed to. However, they expect you to sell your soul. EVERYONE here drinks the Kool-Aid and they all love it. There are 4 - 5 months of the year where people are required work a minimum of 55 chargeable hours each week (checking email/travel/etc. doesn't count) and no one blinks an eye. Everyone here is your stereotypical white collar, frat boy/sorority girl jerk, and if you don't have the same Type A love of sports, getting white-girl wasted, and working your life away, you won't fit in. It's worse than being in high school. I cannot wait to get out.Fulfilled Big 4 Stereotype

A typical day at KPMG was planning an audit. This means checking emails, preparing the current and permanent files for the next audit. working on three to four different audits, meeting with the clients, preparing a clients deliverable list for the clients. Conducting entrance and exist meetings with the clients, filedwork at the clients's business, preparing Management Letter points, audited draft financial statements, training on auditing procedures, analyzing and reviewing the financial statements to ensure accuracy and no errors. Research foreign currency rates for investment securities the Bloomberg System. Review clients' corporate documents at Legal Firms. The majority of the audits required team work unless it was a small audit where one individual did the audit. I worked with a diverse group of people from different cultures around the owrld and I enjoyed working with the team, I developed friendship with most of them and we remained in contact with each other to this day. The hardest part of the job was seeing persons with so much knowledge and skills leave the Company to pursue other careers. Management at KPMG had an opened door policy and was very respecful to all of its employees.Very Productive and Fun place to work

I had a great career at KPMG (Tax) and I left there after 19 years. The firm gave me so many challenging opportunites such as working in federal tax, state tax, professional practice, overseas position, etc. In addition to that, I worked with so many smart people who helped me along the way which gave me a great skill set.

Coming up through the ranks, I had good managers and partners almost the entire time. People who cannot manage, mentor, teach, lead by example, be supportive, be positive and motivate people generally leave after 4-5 years with a great skill set.

The one regret I have is not taking the time to get to know each and every person I worked with.
